wesm commented on issue #4180: ARROW-4139: [C++][Parquet] Logical Type casting for parquet statistics
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4180#issuecomment-486459240
 
 
   I'm also concerned about the maintainability of these changes. I'm still catching up from vacation (including a lot of non-engineering Ursa Labs organization stuff...) but I will carve out some time to have a closer look at this and also @xhochy's changes in https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2623/files. 
   
   Regarding that patch, I want to be careful about introducing unnecessary new public API surface area since we have been discussing porting much of this functionality into C++ so that it can be used in other languages and not just Python (see https://docs.google.com/document/d/1bVhzifD38qDypnSjtf8exvpP3sSB5x_Kw9m-n66FB2c/edit?usp=sharing). Of course, I'm sympathetic to the requirements that you have for Dask so I would like to unblock the use cases you have in the meantime

   From an API perspective it seems like a solution would be to add `min_as_logical` and `max_as_logical` attributes (or similar) to `RowGroupStatistics` here

   I don't think collecting the statistics as a particular pandas DataFrame arrangement is necessarily something we want to maintain, you could have that code in Dask

mpeaton commented on issue #4180: ARROW-4139: [C++][Parquet] Logical Type casting for parquet statistics
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4180#issuecomment-488743270
 
 
   My primary use case is development for this task so really cython debugging of parquet.so using lldb.  I have thus far had trouble setting breakpoints and assumed that maybe the debug builds are not including symbols when $ARROW_BUILD_TYPE is set to debug?...      As a tangent, I noted that some of the cpp tests which appeared related such as test-statistics would fail on my local build, so I also attempted to use docker-compose images running in interactive mode for a complementary build path to check both debugging build symbol presence, as well as cpp test status, but found that docker-compose up eventually failed on my machine.  From my investigation of the docker images in my registry, it appears that they do not have arrow built inside ( or more specifically debug builds ) so overall I am wondering if there is a secret manual I might be missing, and if there are any best practices available that may have been circulated amongst the community.  Thanks for responding @wesm I don't really want to be a burden I'm trying to help here :).
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

wesm commented on pull request #4680: ARROW-4139: [Python][Parquet] Wrap new parquet::LogicalType, cast min/max statistics based on LogicalType
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4680
 
 
   This changes the behavior of `Statistics.min` and `Statistics.max` to return the decoded logical value, such as a UTF-8 string, uint64 value, timestamp, etc.  I added `min_raw` and `max_raw` attributes to return the raw physical type value
   
   Also fixes ARROW-5166 (uint64 as int64 overflow)
   
   I found the `isAdjustedToUTC` parameter for `TIME` logical type to be weird, so I'm changing the Arrow conversion layer to always set this so we can get the TIME_MILLIS / TIME_MICROS converted type to be set in those cases.

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
When writing Pandas data to Parquet format and reading it back again I find that that statistics of text columns are stored as byte arrays rather than as unicode text. 

I'm not sure if this is a bug in Arrow, PyArrow, or just in my understanding of how best to manage statistics.  (I'd be quite happy to learn that it was the latter).

Here is a minimal example

{code:python}
import pandas as pd
df = pd.DataFrame({'x': ['a']})
df.to_parquet('df.parquet')
import pyarrow.parquet as pq
pf = pq.ParquetDataset('df.parquet')
piece = pf.pieces[0]
rg = piece.row_group(0)
md = piece.get_metadata(pq.ParquetFile)
rg = md.row_group(0)
c = rg.column(0)

>>> c
<pyarrow._parquet.ColumnChunkMetaData object at 0x7fd1a377c238>
  file_offset: 63
  file_path: 
  physical_type: BYTE_ARRAY
  num_values: 1
  path_in_schema: x
  is_stats_set: True
  statistics:
    <pyarrow._parquet.RowGroupStatistics object at 0x7fd1a37d4418>
      has_min_max: True
      min: b'a'
      max: b'a'
      null_count: 0
      distinct_count: 0
      num_values: 1
      physical_type: BYTE_ARRAY
  compression: SNAPPY
  encodings: ('PLAIN_DICTIONARY', 'PLAIN', 'RLE')
  has_dictionary_page: True
  dictionary_page_offset: 4
  data_page_offset: 25
  total_compressed_size: 59
  total_uncompressed_size: 55

>>> type(c.statistics.min)
bytes
{code}

My guess is that we would want to store a logical type in the statistics like UNICODE, though I don't have enough experience with Parquet data types to know if this is a good idea or possible.
fields.summary: [Python] Cast Parquet column statistics to unicode if UTF8 ConvertedType is set

comments.body:
Parquet uses BYTE_ARRAY for physical storage of unicode. Currently logical types aren't being considered in the "boxing" logic when accessing the statistics

https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/python/pyarrow/_parquet.pyx#L69

I don't see an issue casting to unicode if the UTF8 ConvertedType is set
We currently always return the physical types in all cases for the statistics. We should add {{logical_(min,max)}} as additional accessors.

Perhaps relatedly, it would be useful to get physical types for statistics of other types.  Here is another issue I ran into with timestamps

{code}
In [1]: import pandas as pd

In [2]: df = pd.util.testing.makeTimeDataFrame()

In [3]: df.head()
Out[3]:
                   A         B         C         D
2000-01-03  1.255856 -1.092558 -1.454595  0.898535
2000-01-04 -1.006590  0.640467 -2.249877  0.068293
2000-01-05 -1.525559  0.567070  1.039230 -0.967301
2000-01-06 -0.773395 -1.565619  0.025786  0.106949
2000-01-07 -0.079000  0.367165  1.746211 -0.097441

In [4]: df.to_parquet('foo.parquet')

In [5]: import pyarrow.parquet as pq

In [6]: p = pq.ParquetDataset('foo.parquet')

In [7]: piece = p.pieces[0]

In [8]: md = piece.get_metadata(open_file_func=lambda fn: open(fn, mode='rb'))

In [9]: rg = md.row_group(0)

In [10]: rg.column(4)
Out[10]:
<pyarrow._parquet.ColumnChunkMetaData object at 0x1203d0670>
  file_offset: 1913
  file_path:
  physical_type: INT64
  num_values: 30
  path_in_schema: __index_level_0__
  is_stats_set: True
  statistics:
    <pyarrow._parquet.RowGroupStatistics object at 0x11f821af8>
      has_min_max: True
      min: 946857600000
      max: 950227200000
      null_count: 0
      distinct_count: 0
      num_values: 30
      physical_type: INT64
  compression: SNAPPY
  encodings: ('PLAIN_DICTIONARY', 'PLAIN', 'RLE')
  has_dictionary_page: True
  dictionary_page_offset: 1635
  data_page_offset: 1842
  total_compressed_size: 278
  total_uncompressed_size: 325

In [11]: rg.column(4).statistics.min  # I want this to be some sort of timestamp object
Out[11]: 946857600000
{code}

Somewhat unrelatedly, there is a lot of boiler plate to get down to that information.  If there are nicer ways to get to statistics I'd be interested in hearing about them.

I was able to access the logical types using pyarrow as:

 
md = piece.get_metadata(pq.ParquetFile)
rg = md.row_group(0)
ps=pq.ParquetSchema(md)
lt = ps.column(i).logical_type


And then do appropriate conversion using decode('UTF8') and np.datetime64() respectively.

[~mrocklin], does it work for you to write an accessor that returns the converted statistics given column? Or what would work best for your use case?

e.g.  get_statistics( column_index )

I don't have strong thoughts about the API.  I mostly care that downstream projects don't have to special case a variety of types.  I expect that that special casing will be quite brittle and break over time.  Ideally we wouldn't be special casing these things in Arrow either.  

My guess is that there is already code somewhere in Arrow that knows how to convert these values in a consistent way.  Hopefully that same code would be engaged for statistics as well, that way we would have confidence that things wouldn't drift in the future.

Have a look at https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2623/files which implements predicate pushdown in Arrow on the Python side. There should also be some code in there that handles the physical to logical conversion.
I added this to my list of things to look at early this week
I submitted a rough WIP PR, in order to facilitate conversation.

The following comment seems to suggest that there is a latent issue sorting unsigned types, specifically mentioning UTF-8.

If this is indeed the case, then would not the sorting have to be fixed before this issue can be resolved?  [https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/de84293d9c93fe721cd127f1a27acc94fe290f3f/cpp/src/parquet/metadata.cc#L140]
I don't think there is a sorting issue with UTF-8 types -- [~mdeepak] worked through this I believe

The statistics are fixed for UTF-8 types. https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/de84293d9c93fe721cd127f1a27acc94fe290f3f/cpp/src/parquet/types.cc#L260
https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/de84293d9c93fe721cd127f1a27acc94fe290f3f/cpp/src/parquet/metadata.cc#L140 is an out of date comment and must be fixed.
See comment here https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/de84293d9c93fe721cd127f1a27acc94fe290f3f/cpp/src/parquet/metadata.cc#L558
I can pick up this one for 0.14.0, but someone else is free to take it from me
